intro: Clidemia crossosepala var. adamsii, commonly known as Adams' stinging nettle, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of Central and South America. It is characterized by its hairy, heart-shaped leaves and small, inconspicuous white flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant produces a milky sap that can cause skin irritation, similar to other members of the Urticaceae family. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forest understories and wetlands. Its botanical features make it an important component of its native ecosystems.
